6FC0F5381D284CD3B99F61EE87AE1657.description:
Apply scientific principles and mathematical representations (C=λv and E=hv) to explain that
spectral lines are the result of and correspond to transitions between energy levels.

B805F9BA2EF149E495D0C6457C69DDDF.description:
Investigate and contrast the mechanism of energy changes and the appearance of absorption
and emission spectra.

23860767369E4AF89EA3DDDB13FDCC42.description:
Waves and Their Applications in Technologies for
Information Transfer

88AA849EA7B1490DB0DEEB88EA82EB74.description:
Research pyrotechnics and use concepts in thermodynamics, stoichiometry, oxidation reduction,
and kinetics to design and create a low intensity sparkler.

6312E28A11D24FF69BDDA02BCF565137.description:
Investigate and explain the energy changes in biological systems (such as the combustion of sugar
and photosynthesis) both qualitatively and quantitatively.

DF6B4E96446C4F51A62B31F52879B613.description:
Explain the relationships between potential energy, distance between approaching atoms, bond
length, and bond energy using graphical representations.

3770BE9B38E24A98A80314F778057C61.description:
Use Coulomb’s law and patterns of valence electron configurations to explain trends in ionization
energies and reactivity of pure elements.

411BC950BC134F05A3626839CF10BBA3.description:
Collect and use data from the synthesis or decomposition of a compound to confirm the
conservation of matter and the law of definite proportions.

2C9BFE3C09994753BC4FC6B66E4F41E5.description:
Apply scientific and engineering ideas to build, evaluate, and refine a fuel cell model (e.g.,
graphical representation or as a project) with specific design constraints.

FB7A63E0479F42FFAE8C540BEA65CCFB.description:
Apply scientific principles and mathematical representations to predict if a chemical reaction is
spontaneous using Gibb’s Free Energy, ΔG = ΔH – TΔS.

0B4AD01FB83A498895A733050858E301.description:
Mathematically determine the enthalpy change for a given reaction using Hess’s Law, standard
enthalpies of formation, or a given mass of a reactant.

61053CFAC7834FC1B62DDDE57A8711EA.description:
Research, investigate, and mathematically explain buffer systems (characteristics and capacities
using the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation), including those found in biological systems and
polyprotic acids.

1936E4B999FA4B83BBAF466C93BA9ED2.description:
Compare and contrast the strength and dissociation of strong and weak acids and bases by
calculating the pH and percent ionization of a solution.

2D7432BF51CE42298223228A536B5536.description:
Investigate the parameters of chemical equilibria in the laboratory by A) writing and calculating
equilibrium expressions (Kc, Kp, Ksp, Ka, Kb); B) calculating Q and determining the direction the
reaction will proceed; and, C) calculating equilibrium concentrations given an equilibrium
constant and starting amounts.

FDE2017DC334434089F9AC69B08B6961.description: Analyze data and mathematically determine rate equations.

5968E399260043D5866220D62A35C9D0.description:
Investigate and use mathematical evidence to support that rates of chemical reactions are
determined by details of the molecular collisions.

24F4187C3E474B9EBDA72BC5E16ECCCC.description:
Make predictions regarding the relative magnitudes of the forces acting within collections of
interacting molecules based on the distribution of electrons within the molecules and types of
intermolecular forces through which the molecules interact.

B4DED41AAB8B45DC8F92AA611EF009A5.description:
Plan and conduct an investigation to compare the properties of the different types of
intermolecular forces in pure substances and in components of a mixture.

791AC6B7FF2D4927978AA110BD8759D8.description: Motion and Stability: Forces and Interactions

0577268AC6B445FDA0F5B657E6EBC1EE.description:
Create a model of the atomic substructure including electrons, protons, neutrons, quarks, and
gluons.

FF0385C7E11C4A62BAE51AC3454FEEEC.description:
Explain common chemical reactions, including those found in biological systems, using
qualitative and quantitative information.

433E76CD3B4B42DB9515059B3EBE050C.description:
Conduct titrations with standard solutions (monoprotic and diprotic) and an appropriate
indicator and/or a pH probe to determine the concentration of an unknown acid or base, and
with a weak acid or weak base to determine the Ka or Kb and the pH at the equivalence point.

8409CACFF72D4431AF4759C6B9D181DD.description: Investigate models and explore uses of electrochemistry (batteries and electrochemical cells).

5FABC8753EDD4258BBE8E5910B1C6F29.description:
Analyze oxidation and reduction reactions to identify the substances gaining and losing
electrons, distinguish between the cathode and anode, predict reactions, and balance oxidation-reduction reactions in acidic or basic solutions.

54B2169992D04BE08FFF36A8A8BCD99B.description:
Conduct a qualitative analysis lab to determine the solubility rules. Use solubility rules to
identify spectator ions and write net ionic equations for precipitation reactions.

EDD9AFD86CF249CB8A34D87305FC55E1.description:
Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about how carbon’s structure and function are
used and have influenced society.

3F6BAF2876D44245A1B42F74BB37DAF3.description:
Evaluate different organic molecules by naming and drawing the ten simplest linear
hydrocarbons and isomers that contain single, double, and/or triple bonds and by identifying
and explaining the properties of functional groups.

BEDC6B0E88E04B8FAF5819DC121B53CE.description:
Develop models to show how different types of polymers, such as proteins, nucleic acids, and
starches, are formed by repetitive combinations of simple subunits by condensation and
addition reactions and to show the diverse bonding characteristics of carbon.

13015F4A8E2448D790B0406CC02C3256.description:
Investigate, describe, and mathematically determine the effect of solute concentration on vapor
pressure using Raoult’s Law and of the solute’s van ’t Hoff factor on freezing point depression
and boiling point elevation.

B4A12E0E2E254F558799EA0B62425505.description:
Use the Van der Waal’s equation to support explanations of how real gases deviate from the
ideal gas law.

9F647380F3C5466E83BBC3621252D1D5.description:
Obtain data and solve combined and ideal gas law problems and stoichiometry problems at STP
and non STP conditions to quantitatively explain the behavior of gases.

9EAFD343B7AA48FD827D46EDC7E6E617.description:
Investigate and use mathematical representations to support Dalton’s law of partial pressures
and to compare and contrast diffusion and effusion.

CD599EAEF1F94F3193F6E1C8B4EDA48B.description:
Compare and contrast crystalline and amorphous solids with respect to particle arrangement,
strength of bonds, melting and boiling points, bulk density, and conductivity; provide examples
of each type.

B685E4B4FBC842E3B29C30EC27F3EDBD.description: Gather evidence and perform calculations to determine the composition of a compound.

7533F16E23EA4C819BF61DE3B3794129.description:
Illustrate and explain the arrangement of electrons surrounding atoms and ions (electron
configurations and orbital notation of a specific electron in an element) and relate the
arrangement of electrons with observed periodic trends.
